header.title: Dragon's Blood #2: Practical Necromancy - Second Edition
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Necromancy, Left Hand Path Magic

central_thesis: This issue of Dragon's Blood explores practical necromancy as a path of self-transformation and magical power, integrating diverse mythological and occult traditions (Draconian, Necronomicon Gnosis, Zoroastrian, Greek, Mesopotamian, Egyptian). It provides both theoretical frameworks and operative techniques for engaging with death, underworld entities, and the subconscious to transcend limitations and achieve spiritual insight.

structure_content.summary: Introduces Dragon Rouge as an international occult order rooted in Sweden, studying magic, occultism, and Gothicism through traditions like Gothic Qabalah, Odinic Runology, Tantrism, and Alchemy. Lodge Magan, the Polish lodge, specifically focuses on Necronomicon gnosis, Tiamat, Cthulhu, Dark Goddesses (Lilith, Hecate, Kali), and Sabbatic Witchcraft, emphasizing the exploration and integration of the 'Shadow' for creative transformation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Azrael and the Death Principle – A Word of Introduction
structure_content.summary: Explores the universal concept of death as a phase of transition and an initiatory experience, personified by various deities and spirits across cultures (Seker, Anubis, Thanatos, Kali, Hel, Ereshkigal, Hecate, Morrigan). Focuses on Azrael, the Angel of Death in Christianity, Judaism, and Islam, detailing his characteristics and function in separating the soul from the body and guiding the dead. Discusses the symbolic meaning of working with death personifications for knowledge and transformation rather than literally seeking death.

A practical ritual designed to invoke Azrael. The practitioner prepares with black and red candles, incense, and a black robe. The ritual involves invocations, visualization of Azrael severing body parts (symbolizing cutting ties to the world), lying in a 'coffin position' to journey through past life, and finally, a 'rebirth' with the black flame of death transforming into the vital force of the 'Great Red Dragon' for inner wholeness and power.

structure_content.chapter_title: Ladies of Infernal Dimensions – Goddesses of Death and Rulers of the Underworld
structure_content.summary: Examines the feminine symbolism of death and the underworld across various mythologies. Discusses Kali (Hindu) and her iconography representing transcendence, destruction, and liberation from karma; Ereshkigal (Babylonian) as the terrifying queen of the underworld; Hel (Norse) as the daughter of Loki and ruler of Helheim, symbolizing the 'hidden' and rebirth; Persephone (Greek) as the maiden abducted by Hades, representing cycles of life/death/resurrection; and Hecate (Greek) as a complex goddess of crossroads, darkness, witchcraft, and keeper of the infernal kingdom.

A ritual aiming to open the practitioner to the 'dark energies' of Persephone for liberation from limitations and the 'planting of new life (consciousness)' in the subconscious. It involves meditating on pomegranate seeds and the mantra 'Lepaca Persephone', followed by an invocation to the 'eternal Queen of the Underworld' to burn barriers with infernal heat, allowing one to see beyond the 'veil of illusion of death'.

Introduces Inhabulos as a little-known demon from the Cthulhu Mythos, lord of the infinite Void and the outer circle of the Underworld, associated with nightmares, leprosy, and madness. He is presented as a guide through the Underworld for necromantic gnosis.

A guided meditation to journey through the Underworld with Inhabulos. It begins by visualizing a dark, empty room with a diamond-framed mirror, upon which a blood offering and the mantra 'Lepaca Inhabulos' opens a portal. The practitioner is drawn into a dark, storm-laden land of moving shadows and carried to an altar where a skull-masked priest performs a ritual, leading to a descent into tunnels of skulls and bones, where one wears a skull mask to hear the voices of the dead and explore.

Explores necromantic practices within the context of Clark Ashton Smith and H.P. Lovecraft's Cthulhu Mythos. Defines necromancy as divination by spirits of the dead, extending to evocation, submergence in crypts, and control over decay. Discusses necromancers who raise the dead (zombies with no free will or driven by vengeance), body possession, and the Charnel God Mordiggian, who devours the dead in Zul-Bha-Sair. Presents various practical methods of necromancy.

Details several practical necromantic techniques: Scrying (observing spirits in a crystal vessel prepared under specific astrological conditions); Necromantic Evocation (summoning animal spirits for skills, or human spirits using a 'shoggoth' or Durson and ashes); How to Make Use of a Corpse (summoning a Yoth fly for essence, creating 'Powder of Desiccation', or ritual cannibalism for knowledge/power); Summoning a Dead Deity (a ritual in a secret place); Travelling to Cutha (opening the Gate of Ganzir to Ereshkigal's underworld); The Arrow of Ghat (a ritual tool to locate sorcerers' graves); Priests of Nyarlathotep's method (boiling corpses into salts to reconstitute bodies for souls); Creating Zombies (shamans invoking demons into corpses); and Soul Bottles (capturing souls for secrets, strength, or torment, granted by Shub Niggurath).

structure_content.chapter_title: Descent into the Temple of the Sphinx – a pathworking
structure_content.summary: A pathworking performed during the New Moon to enhance awareness of the individual astral Shadow. It involves visualizing entering a Sphinx statue on a desert night, descending into underground corridors with ghastly music, passing a veiled priest, and entering a hall filled with animated skeletons and ghoul-like creatures. The pathworking culminates in confronting a Sphinx-like Nyarlathotep, a symbolic dissolution of the body into a cauldron of black fire, and subsequent rebuilding as a 'shadow' filled with the 'force of darkness'.

Introduces Niantiel, the sentinel of the 24th tunnel on the Tree of Night, corresponding to Death (XIII), offering gnosis of death-reincarnation and conscious awareness of mortality. The pathworking begins at a grotesque carnival, where a pale woman offers wine (blood-like), leading to paralysis and the vision of one's own funeral. The body is devoured by a wolf, leading to a dissolution of all stability and a burst of laughter and ecstasy as limitations are broken, and one follows the 'sun of the dead' into the unconscious.

Describes the Mesopotamian cosmological view of the underworld, located below the sweet waters of Absu, surrounded by the salt ocean of Tiamat. It is separated from the living by the river Hubur, crossed by a boatman. The underworld is depicted as a gloomy, dust-filled land of no return where souls suffer hunger and thirst. Discusses its guardians (Neti, Lugal-irra, Meslamta-ea) and rulers, Ereshkigal and Nergal, highlighting myths where deities (Inanna, Nergal) interact with this realm.

structure_content.chapter_title: Nitocris – the Queen of Ghouls and the Lady of the Pyramid
structure_content.summary: Explores Nitocris from historical accounts (Pharaoh of 6th Dynasty, Queen of Babylon) and her integration into the Cthulhu Mythos. In Lovecraft's lore, she is connected to Nephren-Ka and Nyarlathotep, often appearing as a priestess, guardian of a mirror to the Great Old Ones, or the 'queen of ghouls' with a partially decayed face, worshipping Nyarlathotep in an underground temple beneath the Sphinx.

Introduces Nas as a Zoroastrian demon of pollution and contamination ('dead matter'), linked to the concept of 'nisrushtih'. In Zoroastrianism, contact with Nas or dead matter leads to impurity and sin. The article suggests that Nas embodies the moral perversion of Yatukih (necrophilia, somnophilia) and can be summoned to explore the secrets of decay, awakening the 'Black Flame' (Ahrimanic essence) in man. Includes a pathworking to invoke Nas through a visualization of carrion and a dense dark shadow.

key_concepts.definition: Divination by means of the spirits of the dead, expanded to include evocation, communication, manipulation of the dead (or their remnants), and journeys to the Underworld for knowledge, power, and personal transformation.

A Left Hand Path magical system rooted in the Dragon Rouge order, focused on exploring and integrating the 'Shadow' in man's soul, transforming destructive principles into creative ones, and pursuing self-deification through confrontation with primal forces and death.

A system of working based on the Cthulhu Mythos, focusing on entities like Tiamat, Leviathan, Cthulhu, and Dagon as 'Chaos Dragons' and 'Sea Dragons' that serve as gateways to the subconscious and immortal aspects of the human self.

A magical tradition involving working with dark, chthonic deities (e.g., Lilith), lunar/Saturnian energies, and practices often conducted in wild, desolate places to reconnect with primeval nature and engage in antinomian 'stepping outside mental limits'.

Conceptualized not merely as an end, but as a transition, an initiator of change, a source of profound knowledge, and a means for spiritual and personal transformation, often personified by various deities or angels across diverse mythologies.

The deep, unexplored layers of the subconscious and dark aspects of the human soul. The goal of Dragon Rouge is to explore and integrate this Shadow to transform it into a creative principle and find inspiration and knowledge.

A guided meditation or visualization technique used to induce altered states of consciousness, explore magical realms (such as the Underworld), interact with specific entities, or facilitate spiritual transformation by engaging with symbolic narratives.

Refers to the 'shells' or 'husks' representing the dark, chaotic, or unbalanced aspects of the Tree of Life in a reverse Qabalistic system, often explored in Left Hand Path magic for gnosis and transgression. Specifically mentioned in relation to Niantiel's tunnel between A'Arab Zaraq and Thagirion.

practical_system.description: The practical system presented is a syncretic approach to necromancy, drawing heavily from Draconian and Necronomicon Gnosis frameworks. It is designed to facilitate profound initiatory experiences and access to hidden knowledge and power by engaging directly with the forces of death, the underworld, and various death-related deities and entities. The practices range from ceremonial invocations and guided pathworkings for self-transformation to more transgressive and operative methods for communicating with, manipulating, and even 'reanimating' the dead, or utilizing their essence. The core aim is to integrate the 'Shadow' aspect of the self, transcend limitations, and achieve a heightened state of consciousness and magical potency.
tools: Hair, skin, fingernails, bone from a corpse
Corpses (dogs, men, rats) and tar (for Arrow of Ghat preparation)
rituals: The Arrow of Ghat (for locating sorcerer graves)
Priests of Nyarlathotep method (reanimating for knowledge)
Descent into the Temple of the Sphinx Pathworking
Invocation of Daevas/Angra Mainyu/Ahriman and Nas

relevant_quotes.text: "Necromancy": divination by means of the spirits of the dead, from the Greek word "nekos", dead; and "manteria", divination.
"But Man possesses the Sign, the Number, and the Shape to summon the Blood of his Parents. And this is the Covenant."
"My heart is made a necromancer's glass, Where homeless forms and exile phantoms teem, Where faces of forgotten sorrows gleam And dead despairs archaic peer and pass" (C.A.Smith "Necromancy")

"Then, in the ashy sand by the wayside, they drew a threefold circle; and standing together at its center, they performed the abominable rites that compel the dead to arise from tranquil nothingness and obey henceforward, in all things, the dark will of the necromancer. Afterward they sprinkled a pinch of magic powder on the nostril-holes of the man and the horse; and the white bones, creaking mournfully, rose up from where they had lain and stood in readiness to serve their masters."

"Fill yourself with corruption and from it you shall be reborn, even as the fungi arise and glow with radiance on the faces of the dead who have rested in their tombs a span of years. Emulate the beetles and worms, and learn their teachings. Eat of the dead, lest you be consumed by the emptiness. The living cannot teach the dead, but the dead can instruct the living."
"Where the last of the borders is crossed"
'The subterranean nymph that dwells 'Mid sunless gems and glories hid - The lady of the Pyramid!'
The demon Nas is he who causes the pollution and contamination (nisrushtih), which they call nasai ('dead matter').

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is highly relevant within contemporary Left Hand Path (LHP) and Draconian magical currents, particularly for practitioners interested in the explicit application of Necronomicon Gnosis and mythological syncretism in necromantic practice. It offers a structured approach to themes often considered taboo or metaphorical in other systems, providing both theoretical grounding in diverse death mythologies and explicit practical methodologies. Its emphasis on self-transformation through confronting death and the subconscious aligns with core LHP tenets, positioning it as a valuable resource for advanced practitioners seeking profound initiatory experiences.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience consists primarily of experienced occultists and magicians already engaged with or exploring Left Hand Path, Draconian, or Chaos Magic traditions. It is particularly suited for those with an interest in Necronomicon-derived systems, dark goddess worship, and transgressive magic. The text explicitly warns against engagement by 'emotionally disturbed individuals or those who suffer from psychic disorders', indicating its intensity and the need for a stable psychological foundation. It is not intended for beginners or those unfamiliar with core occult concepts and practices.
